SUPERIMPOSED over this fountain are the mai and credit titles. Throughout the running of the titles w hear castanet music growing louder and louder. When the l credit title FADE OFF we begin to

The corridor, backstage at El Pueblo. An empty corridor stretches away before us. The CAMERA TRUCKS ALONG this corridor. The sound of the castanets is so loud and ringi now that it has a furious and stormlike quality. The came seems to search for the source of this sound. It approach two open doorways at the end of the corridor. Through the doorway on the right we see a dancer in Spani costume. She pirouettes in a final whirl of the dance as CAMERA MOVES IN TO a CLOSE SHOT of her beautiful back and two castanets she holds up over her gleaming naked should Over the diminishing trill of the castanets, as the dance finishes her dance we hear a dull and angry pounding. The castanets click to an end. The CAMERA MOVES LEFT to take in the adjoining door to sh us the source of this sound.

Kiki Walker as she finishes pounding on the wall for sile in the adjoining dressing room and turns back into her ow room. She is young, blonde and represents that peculiar phenomenon of our time, the chorus girl and entertainer w is more lady-like than the majority of Junior Leaguers. R shows, one night stands and even a short turn in burlesqu have left no battle scars. She may know many a hard word, she never uses it. MED. SHOT - Kiki's room. Kiki slams shut the door of her dressing room. Her dressing room is a small bare cubicle a sink, easy chair, dressing table and a long mirror on t closet door. On the dressing table, among a clutter of ja and ointments, is a small musical trinket box. The closet door is partially ajar. In the room with Kiki is Eloise, the cigarette girl at th Pueblo, a brightly blondined young lady. Her nether limbs well display in black stockings. A cigarette tray is slun over her shoulder.
(as she walks across the room) It may sound like music to her -- I can do better with my teeth in a cold Shower. (mockingly) Click В— click В— click.
(shrugging) She's a local. When the dudes come out to New Mexico, they went to wallow in Latin glamour. This is a bad town for blondes.
Yes. So I've noticed. Jerry's noticed -В— He'll come up with something.
You think be's pretty nice, don't you?
Why not? He's a good press agent and a good friend. Besides, we've shared a lot of headaches В—В—
You're lucky. I wish he'd front page for me.
Maybe. For three years I've sung in rats' nests, while Jerry pounded his feet off and his brains out -- trying to get me a real chance. We're due for a little luck!

Kiki walks across to the make-up table and sits down in f of it, lifting her hands to unwrap the towel which is wra around her head to protect it from make-up. Eloise starts toward the door, but pauses to admire herself in the mirr
I don't mean this personally, Miss Walker, but it's ironic В—-
She pauses, striking a pose the better to look at her own sleek legs in the minor.
I mean you being a star and me being just a cigarette girl.
(turning from (the mirror to look at Eloise) I know. I know. You've got the talent. I got the breaks.
She turns back to the mirror. NED. CLOSE REFLECTION SHOT of Eloise. We see Eloise admir herself in the long mirror and also the edge of the dress room door as it slowly begins to swing open.
I hear it in night club.

Eloise can see what is opening the door. She lets loose w a shriek of mortal terror. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Kiki. She whirls quickly and rises, he mouth open in a soundless ejaculation of fright. REVERSE SHOT - the door. Through the doorway comes the bl spade-shaped head of a panther, ears wickedly flat, muzzl the floor. He starts into the room with a terrifying zigz undulation. Eloise yips feebly. Kiki screams. As the panther advances into the room, one can see that i held on a taut leash. Holding the leash is Jerry Manning, with a wide, pleasant smile of reassurance on his lips. CLOSE SHOT Kiki on top of the dressing table. She stands there holding her dressing gown back across her knees in terror. The little jewel box has fallen to the floor, and insipid tinkling tune fills the room as it rolls across t floor toward the panther. MED. SHOT - Kiki, Eloise, Jerry and the panther. Kiki sta on top of the dressing table; Eloise has retreated behind chair, and Jerry stands between them, grinning, holding t leash of the panther, which is nosing forward to examine music box
(hitting high C) Get it out of here!
Kiki -- he won't hurt you. There's nothing to be afraid of.
Makes no difference. Get him out!
Listen, Kicks, you'll never guess what I've cooked up this tine...
That's easy. Me.

I thought -- is Kiki just going to walk on that floor tonight В—В—walk out cold before a bunch of gawks who think a Spanish twirler is the greatest thing in life. No. Not my favorite client. She's going to make an entrance this town will never forget!
(pointing to the leopard) On his back, I suppose.
(kidding her) No. I thought that might be just a little corny. I want you to lead him in on a leash.
You're too good to me.
Look, Kicks, have I ever done anything to hurt you?
No В—- not yet.
(quite sincerely and with evident affection) And I never will- you know what's between us В— we're a thing  But this is serious competition.
(hitting high C) Get it out of here!
Kiki - he won't hurt you. There's nothing to be afraid of.
Makes no difference.  Get him out.
Listen, Kicks, you'll never guess what I've cooked up this time.
That's easy. Me.

I thought -В— is Kiki just going to walk on that floor tonight walk out cold before a bunch of gawks who think a Spanish twirler is the greatest thing in life. No. Not my favorite client. She's going to make an entrance  this town will never forget.
(pointing to the leopard) On his back, I suppose.
(kidding her) No. I thought that might be just a little corny.  I want you to lead him in on a leash.
You're too good to me.
(sentimentally) Look, Kicks, how long have we known each other?
(flatly) This is l939. Can't you subtract?
Almost three years, isn't it? And have I ever done anything to hurt you?
No В—В— not yet.
(quite sincerely and with evident affection) And I never will -- you know what's between us -В— we're a thing -- But this is serious -- big competition.
Clo-Clo?
(indicating leopard) I thought you might strut this kitten in right in the middle of her act.
Kiki grins. Jerry reaches for Kiki's hand, and passes the of the leash over her fingers.
Come down to earthВ— and see what a picture you'd make with this for a pet.
Keeping a wary eye on the leopard, Kiki lets Jerry help h down. She stands as far away from the beast as the leash permit.
(warily, from behind the chair) And if you've got cold feet honey, Ill take over for you. That red dress of yours fits just perfect on me.
(exasperated, turning to her) I bet you try on my coffin some day -- I hope it "fits just perfect."
(hastily to Kiki) You look swell in that threeВ—alarm number --
The red dress? (thinks a moment) No. My black one. Then I'll be just like him.

CL0SE SHOT - the fountain. The CAMERA is FOCUSED on the extreme height of the jet of water. We watch the ball on of this jet as it rises and falls for a few beats. Over t shot we hear the music of a Mexican orchestra. The CAMERA MOVES DOWN and BACK to reveal the upper tier o the fountain with the water flowing over its edges.  The CAMERA MOVES BACK and we see the wide pool at the bas the fountain. In this pool we see Clo-Clo reflected, as s dances. The CAMERA PANS to take in the actual dancer and we see C Clo whirling and turning in a tight circle. She is illuminated by several baby spots concealed at the base of the fountain, and this light makes a nimbus of light around her. It is a sort of superaura which washes out th background haze, leaving the dancer clear-cut and sharp i the midst of this superaura. As Clo-Clo's dance widens in movement, taking her to the of the light nimbus, we can see her, the tables and the patrons of El Pueblo. The El Pueblo cafe is the smartest night club in this sma New Mexican resort town. The main dining room is in the patio. Here are tables mantled in snowy tablecloths, glittering candlelight and sparkling glassware. On the po is an open space for the performers and the orchestra on side  On the other side is a bar. Tonight, El Pueblo is crowded. Waiters, dressed in rather formal costumes with black trousers and short, white coat scurry between the tables. A good portion of -the patrons in evening clothes. CloВ—Clo dances. The rhythmic rattle of her castanets bea above the orchestra. Clo-Clo is New Mexican. Like the broncos of her native st she is all fine, proud, pure Spanish blood. It has suffer change in the high clear air of New Mexico. In her dance, too, we see the more primeval strain of the Indian twiste among the finer threads of Spanish rhythm. She dances. In the pool we see the heavy flutter and turn her skirt. Her neck, her bosom, her arms, bend and sway a turn and pulse with the bloodbeat of the castanets. She i just entering a graceful turn of the dance, the castanets beginning a glissade, when suddenly she stops dead, the c of the castanets cutting off abruptly. REVERSE SHOT - the doorway leading into the El Pueblo. Fr in this doorway is Kiki, slim and tall in a black gown wi black gloves, and in her outstretched hand is a black lea which links her to the leopard. Behind her the doorway is with light so that we see her dramatic outline, a silhoue against luminosity. MED. LONG SHOT - the cafe. A buzz of amazement sounds fro the crowd. There is a flutter of astonishment and timidit CLOSEUP of CloВ—Clo. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Kiki. Behind her in the doorway Jerry Manning's face appears. It is obvious that Kiki, despite dramatic pose, is surreptitiously nervous.
(sotto voce) Don't stand here, Kiki. You're on stage. They're looking at you.

Kiki moves majestically forward. MED. LONG SHOT В— a table near the dance space. Kiki, the leopard moving before her, threads her way between two tables, the patrons drawing away from her black escort as passes. A waiter, carefully holding the chair between him the leopard, makes a place for her at an empty table. CloВ—Clo, feet wide apart, arms and hands still half rais and holding the castanets, watches. The orchestra plays feebly on. Suddenly CloВ—Clo smiles. She lifts her hands a little hi takes a step forward and lets the castanets loose with a that sounds like machineВ—gun fire. The leopard startled, twists in a half turn of fright, strains suddenly at the leash and lunges forward. The leash pulls out of Kiki's frightened hand. REFLECTION SHOT in the pool. The still water reflects the quick bound and leap of the leopard in its panic flight f freedom. MED. CLOSE SHOT - Kiki. She stands leaning against the ta trembling in fright. Behind her CloВ—Clo can be seen can seen on the platform, smiling. Jerry comes into the scene puts his arm about Kiki's waist.
Are you all right?
(wildly, and in disgust) Now look what you've done.
The familiar tone of anger reassures Jerry.
(briefly) You are all right.

MED. SHOT - the leopard bounding through the gate. MED. SHOT at the gate. A waiter with a napkin over his ar and a water carafe in his hand, stands aghast, pressing h back to the wall in fear. The water carafe falls with a crash. The waiter holds up his hand, dazed. His hand is streaming with blood.

SHOT of four policemen, their backs toward us, going thro the Alley of the Shadows. Two of them are beating on pots pans to make a noise. Two others are flashing their flashlights from one side to the other. We TRUCK WITH them down the alley. They bring us to the o end of the passage, athwart which a fire truck is parked. Near this fire truck stands the Chief of Police, Robles, dignified, wellВ—spoken, Mexican police officer, serious conscientious, very much on duty at all times.
No leopard, Chief -- no cat, no kittens, nothing. We're going to tackle the houses

Robles nods. He makes a gesture to one of the men on the truck and two long lances of light pierce the darkness of alley. LONG SHOT - Pasaje De Las Sombras. The shafts of light fr the searchlights cross and re-cross, moving, as they expl the dark jags and corners of the alley. It is one of the oldest streets in town, so narrow that even at noonday, t sun has difficulty lightening its dark shadows. The adobe houses, standing wall to wall, were never built on any straight geometric line; the street makes a dog-leg, meandering, as if loathe to reach its own blind end. MED. LONG SHOT В— the mouth of the alley at the other sid the fire truck. This is a-scene of curiosity and confusio police cordon has been erected, and several uniformed Mex policemen are busy shooing away the spectators, foiling t attempts of small boys to get under the ropes, and genera trying to reduce chaos to an ordered hunt for the leopard At the mouth of the alley, next to the fire truck is park curious conveyance, a half-ton truck with a gaudy sign wh reads:

Leaning against a fender of this vehicle is Jerry Manning hot, disheveled and excited. He is talking with a short Indian, Charlie HowВ—Come, dressed in Levis, a velvet Zun jacket, and with a battered felt hat on his coarse black hair.
Remember what you said: Ten bucks for the loan of my cat В—-two hundred and twenty-five if anything happened to it.
Jerry tries to control his exasperation.
(with strained patience) But nothing has happened to it. It got into this alley, and there's no way out of it. They'll find it.

You don't get the idea, Mister. These cops banging those pans, flashing those lights -В— they're going to scare that poor cat of mine, Cats are funny. They don't want to hurt you -- but if you scare them -В— they go crazy. These cops don't know what they're doing.

A little Mexican boy who has seen listening to the conversation between Jerry and Charlie, is suddenly attra by something off in the darkness. Grinning, he turns on t hand flashlight he is holding and points it off into the darkness of the alley. MED. CLOSE SHOT - Clo-Clo's legs. The flashlight picks up pair of shapely legs and holds on them as they move forwa The legs stop their walking motion and suddenly begin to stamp with the heel taps that are part of her dance. The light snaps off. MED. SHOT - Jerry and Charlie. CloВ—Clo comes in from the left. She grins at the men.
(to Jerry) Maybe, Mr. Manning would like to help me? I do not need a leopard. I have talent.
Jerry is furious and about to make some retort. CloВ—Clo laughs and takes her hands from her pockets. She is holdi her castanets, and a ribald rattle drowns anything Jerry might want to say.
(moving off) Goodnight, Mr. Publicity Man.
Jerry glares after her.

This is a small flower shop. One or two vases hold wilted flowers which have been left in the display window. Behin them is a mirror. In this mirror we can see the mouth of alley and Clo-Clo as she walks away from the men and come toward the flower shop.

CloВ—Clo passes the flower shop and continues on. The CAMERA TRUCKS WITH her. She passes several dark doorw and comes abreast of a dimly lit shop. Behind the grimy window of this store is a large handВ—lettered sign:
From the dark doorway of this store, a voice calls out.
Why are you hurrying, Clo-Clo?
(with a derisive twitter of her castanets) Oh, it's you. Faker!
Suddenly a white, thin hand and arm appears from the shad of the doorway. The hand holds a deck of cards, extending them toward Clo-Clo temptingly.
Take a card, Clo-Clo. See what the night holds for you.
Clo-Clo hesitates. Looks at the deck of cards.
Your cards are a joke. I wouldn't give you a centavo.
She starts to move away.
One card CloВ—Clo -- for nothing.

Clo-Clo stops. Pretending indifference, she casually reac out and takes a card. INSERT        ACE OF SPADES in Clo-Clo's hand. MED. CLOSE SHOT of CloВ—Clo as she stares at the card. Sh laughs and flips the card back into the darkness of the doorway, letting the castanets in her other hand speak of disbelief.
Faker!

She starts off along the street. CAMERA TRUCKS WITH her. She passes an open doorway. In th shadow lounges a tall thin man, his figure merging with t darkness. He is smoking. We can see the glow of his cigarette.
(in passing) Hello, Shorty.

The man disregards a verbal reply, but blows a smoke ring toward her. She pokes' her index finger through the ring playfully and goes on. The CAMERA MOVES WITH her. In the area way of the next building are two lovers, pressed close to each other and close to the wall..
Oo! Oo!
(protestingly) Clo-Clo.
Clo-Clo goes on. From a window a young girl is peeping, looking up and down the street with large frightened eye
(smiling) Hello, Chiquita.
(smiling back, a little hesitantly) Hello, Clo-Clo.

Clo-Clo goes on, but our CAMERA REMAINS. This is Teresa Delgado, a wisp of a young girl, whose childish, smooth f might go unnoticed if it were not for her enormous and wistful dark eyes. She has on a skimpy cotton dress drawn at the waist with a five-and-ten cent store belt. Having looked again up and down the street she pulls down the sa and turns back into the room.

The Delgado house is typical of the poorer Mexican homes New Mexico. This main room, which is small, serves as liv room, bedroom and kitchen. An Indian blanket covers the doorway into the only other room. The adobe walls are plastered with pictures of religious subjects. The wooden floor is bare. There is a charcoal-burning bra in one corner. Pots and pans on the hearth of the firepla show that it is a supplementary stove, The rest of the furniture consists of an iron bedstead, a large and hideo oak table and an open-faced china cabinet which contains Delgado treasures. Pedro, Teresa's nine-year-old brother is seated at the oa table, eating from a bowl of frijoles. He is, and looks l an imp. Teresa is backing away from her mother, who turns away from the window to face her angrily.
(evidently resuming a discussion) But, Mamacita -- why can't Pedro go this time? I'm so tired...
(complacently) I'm too young.

If your father comes home and there are no tortillas, he will shout В—В— and tomorrow it will be all over town: the family of Juan Delgado is too poor to buy corn meal! Do you wish we should be so disgraced?
Teresa shakes her head, but makes no move to go. Exaspera Sra. Delgado reaches for the nearest weapon -- the broom.
Then go!
Sra. Delgado brandishes the broom toward Teresa, who back again.
I know what she's afraid of...
Pedro lifts his hand. It casts a sharp shadow on the wall behind him. Watching the shadow, he manipulates his finge so as to create the shadow of a leopard's head in miniatu
This!
And what, por todos los santos, is "this"?
Teresa braves the threatening broom and moves a step towa her mother.
(eager to be believed) The leopard, Mamacita. They say a lady at the El Pueblo had it on a string and it ran away. It hasn't been found yet...
A leopard?
(gleefully) They're big -- and they jump on you!
Pedro jumps the shadow on the wall, to simulate the leap leopard.
(furiously) Did you ever meet one of those things yet when you went to the store for me?
Teresa swallows, shakes her head mutely.
(bellowing) Then you won't meet one this time either! Now get out! Do as I told you!

Sra. Delgado gives the broom such a backward swing of fin purpose that Teresa hurriedly opens the door behind her a slinks out backwards -- her big liquid dark eyes, still futilely pleading, the last to disappear. Sra. Delgado mo after her, pushing the door closed. She puts the broom in the corner and goes to where Pedro seated. Here she stands a moment, fondly watching him as masticates his beans. Behind her the door stealthily open Teresa tries to sneak back into the room. Mamacita sees t movement and makes a tempestuous rush toward her, but Ter sidles out of the door before she can be caught. Mamacita muttering, slams the door shut and with difficulty pushes heavy, rust-covered iron bolt into place.
Teresa stands outside the door. We hear the heavy bolt in driven home forcibly.
Now В—В— you will not come in again, not until you bring the corn meal with you!

Teresa steps down from the single doorstep outside her ho She crosses her arms and pulls her shoulders together in gesture of fear. She looks once, despairingly, at the clo door behind her В—В— and then reluctantly steps out into dirt road and starts walking.

Only a large corner window, with the word. "Provisiones" printed on it shows that this ordinary house is a grocery store. In the moonlight, one can see a few boxes of groce stacked on shelves inside. Teresa comes up to the window peers in. She knocks on the window.
Senora Calderon It is Teresa, Senor. Teresa Delgado.

Over Teresa's shoulder, we see the interior of the little store light up dimly as a curtain is pulled at the back o the room. Beyond the curtain is revealed another room, brightly lit by a bare electric globe hanging from the ceiling on a cord. Under the light, a man sits at a table heartily eating from a plate heaped with food. The curtai has been pulled back by Senora Calderon. We see her only silhouette and the details of her face and figure are indistinguishable. We do see, however, that her long blac hair is down her back and she is braiding it. She walks a little ways into the darkened store.
(speaking loudly to be heard through the window) The store is closed.
I just want a sack of corn meal for my father's supper!
Tomorrow.
(imploringly) It'll just take a second. ..Please В—В—or I must go clear across the Arroyo to the big grocery --
Teresa taps against the window hopefully. But Sra. Calder turns back toward the doorway into the inner room, where solitary feaster hasn't even bothered to look up during t exchange.
(as she goes) It means taking off the lock again, putting on the light, measuring the meal. It's too much trouble. Once I close, I close!

Sm. Calderon steps into the inner room and draws the curt closed behind her, as she speaks the last words. Again th store is in darkness -- only a rim of light showing aroun the edges of the curtained doorway.
(quietly В— hopelessly) Senora...
There is no reply. Teresa turns away.

The Arroyo is a deep narrow cut in the mesa, boneВ—dry in season. Its floor of bleached sand and weeds stretches desolately wider a vast moonlit sky. Here and there, children's feet have scuffed steep little trails down the banks. Teresa appears at the top of one of these trails. She loo down into the Arroyo -- and then off to the right. A distance down the Arroyo is a bridge which carries a tr track across the dry river bed. To divert the rush of rai water in winter and spring, the bridge is underpropped by slanting stone piers. They stand out like ribs against th blackness of the underpass, which they divide into three tunnels. Teresa's face shows her dread of the Arroyo. She turns ba the way she came, takes a step away, hesitates and then returns to the edge of the bank. She starts down the little trail, her feet sliding in the loose sand and a shower of pebbles bouncing down ahead of her.
Teresa stands at the bottom of the bank. She looks off to bridge again. Then she starts walking forward slowly, a v little figure in the large loneliness of the night.

Teresa comes up to the face of the underpass with its thr openings. She stares from one black tunnel mouth to anoth She glances behind her, then looks at the underpass again Teresa goes forward again, toward the middle tunnel.

The roof of the underpass is only a little higher than Teresa's head and the passage is not more than ten feet w The opening is dimly lit by the moonlight, but beyond it dense blackness. Teresa enters slowly. She takes a few st toward the blackness В—- and stops. She listens. Teresa m forward again, walking as lightly as possible. The light rapidly, so that after Teresa has taken a half dozen step she is swallowed up in complete blackness. The CAMERA HOLDS for a moment on the dark underpass befor Teresa emerges from the blackness on the West side. A lig scratching sound is heard. Teresa's eyes widen in panic a she hears it and she hurries out of the tunnel, watching fearfully ever her left shoulder. She must cut across in front of this other tunnel in order to get to the south b She starts across, never taking her eyes off the black tu mouth. Suddenly she gives a convulsive start and a little escapes before she can control it. A shadowy shape, low t the ground, detaches itself from the dimness of the tunne opening and moves toward her. Almost at once, we see that is a large tumbleweed, blowing clown the Arroyo in the wi Teresa sighs soundlessly and goes on to the foot of the b She starts scrambling up another steep little path.

This is a fairly goodВ—sized room, lined with shelves and counters. A tall, Indian-type Mexican with iron-grey hair puts a paper sack of cornmeal on the counter in front of Teresa. She starts toward the door, but noticing a bronze cage wi two toy birds in it, a mechanical device which has stood there for years, she goes toward it, puts down her sack o corn meal and goes up close.
Oh, the toy birds!
You've seen them before. I couldn't chase you away from the counter when you were a little girl.
She winds up the bird cage.
I'd forgotten them.

(smiling, goodhumoredly, skeptical) Every day you see them --and you have forgotten them? Oh, I remember my little Teresita -- I remember the little girl who was afraid of the dark. They shouldn't send you.
The birds have begun to sing,a highly mechanical renderin a bird song.
I'm not afraid. What could happen to me?

The birds sing and she pretends to listen. Manuel leans against the inner door of the grocery watching her, smili and amused. Finally his smiling irks her into action. She picks up her sack of corn meal.
(as she starts off) I'll pay you tomorrow.
Never fear - - next time you come. The poor don't cheat one another. We're all poor together.
In the bronze cage the two birds continue to sing their mechanical song. Their heads turn from side to side. We hear the door close behind Teresa. The birds are still singing as we

There is a sound of slow, measured dripping. It comes fro water seeping out between two rocks and dropping onto ano rock below. These rocks are piled up at the juncture of t bridge and the left bank and the water is evidently leaki from some water main or sews go pipe running under the highway overhead.

Teresa is approaching the entrance of the middle tunnel, is evidently scared В—- her footsteps are lagging and she holds the sack of corn meal in both hands, as if feeling weight. She looks fearfully at the black tunnel before he and comes to a standstill, trying to peer into the blackn In the silence, the dripping of the water can be heard. Teresa looks up and to the left to locate the sound. She the shining dampness on the rocks. She turns back to the middle tunnel before her -- and, drawing a deep breath of resolution, starts to enter it. But she hesitates and the suddenly, veers over to the left. She peers into the open of that tunnel.
The wall of the tunnel is also damp with the seepage from above. It reflects the outer moonlight in glistening stre so that the blackness here is not so complete as in the o tunnel..
Teresa gets a fresh grip on the bag of corn meal by shift her hands under it -- and walks into the entrance of the north tunnel.

Again, the crunching sound of Teresa's footsteps are magnified in the enclosure of the tunnel walls. It is ver dim, but the luminosity of the damp wall casts a faint li on Teresa, reflecting in her wide, frightened eyes. She w slowly and lightly, her eyes going from side to side in t darkness, her neck and head held rigidly. Suddenly she st with a sharp intake of breath, Ahead of her and to her le are two tiny gleams of light. Teresa backs away from them she does so, they seem to fall and vanish. Slowly Teresa moves forward again, staring at the place w the lights had been. As she moves parallel to the spot, t appear again. A half-cry dies away in her throat --she se that the gleams are two drops of seepage, trickling down side of the tunnel wall. Teresa half closes her eyes and sways a little, faint with fear. Then she forces herself move forward again. She takes one -- two fearful steps -- then the underpass reverberates with a sudden tremendous shock of sound -В— more a giant vibration than actual noi It is a train passing overhead.

As Teresa stands transfixed, the terrific roar continues. Second after second, flashes of light as brilliant as lightning illuminate the interior of the tunnel В— the reflections thrown into the Arroyo by the train windows. then, as abruptly as it began, the noise ceases. It is cavernously dark in the tunnel again. In this thick stillness, Teresa walks forward once more.

In the frame of the tunnel opening, Teresa stands for a moment. Behind her, there is a new sound -- a mere whispe sound carried forward on the light wind. A little shower rubble falls from the top of the concrete pier. Teresa tu to look behind her. Crouched on one of the piers of the trestle -В— and seen very dimly in the darkness -- is the leopard, looking dow into the Arroyo. An enormous big HEAD CLOSEUP of Teresa. An enormous big HEAD CLOSEUP of the leopard, its clear go eyes fixed and staring.

Teresa's nails dig into the paper sack of corn meal and little trickles of the meal start spilling from the slits Her eyes widen and her face falls slack from the horrible shock of what she sees. She turns and runs.

Teresa scrambles frantically up over the edge of the bank She stumbles ana falls and the sack of corn meal drops fr her hands and spills onto the ground. In a single move, Teresa is on her feet and running again. A shadow flashes over the spilled meal and we hear a heavy, ripping snarl.

It is quiet and peaceful in the Delgado home. Senora Delg is puttering about the brasero. Pedro, on all fours, is reading a comic book, his rump high in the air, his chin inches from the book. Suddenly, a wild rain of knocks on door fill the little room. Sonora Delgado, at the brasero drops a spoon with a clatter and Pedro springs up.
(screaming) Mamacita, let me in! Let me in, let me in!
Hah!
Sonora Delgado smirks knowingly and puts her hands on her hips.
If you love me, let me in -- !
(mimicking Teresa) Mamacita -- let me in. Let me in, now that I've spent half the night getting the corn meal!
It's coming -В— it's coming closer. I can see it...
She is afraid of the leopard.
Just what she needs -- something to nip at her heels and hurry her up -
